messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>
> Alexandru Popescu â˜€ wrote:
>
> > JMock 2.x (this one is imo a mess: they
> > moved from string-based method invocation to more static approach,
> but they
> > have completely screwed the API)
>
> I think there is a lot of strong opinion, both positive and negative, to
> the JMock 2 API. Smalltalkers and Rubyists love it, others hate it. It's
> the most creative use of Java I've ever seen and if the API fails, I
> blame Java, not JMock.
>
> >From their web site:
>
> context.checking(new Expectations() {{
> one (subscriber).receive(message);
> }});

I wrote a little helper class for Groovy which makes this have a
more streamlined feel without altering the essential JMock2 style:

context.checking{
one(subscriber).receive(message)
}

You can find more details here:

http://groovy.codehaus.org/Using+JMock+with+Groovy

On the parent page:

http://groovy.codehaus.org/Using+Testing+Frameworks+with+Groovy

You will find links to the same examples done for EasyMock, GSpec,
Instinct, JBehave, JDummy, JMock1/2, JMockit, RMock and TestNG.

The examples include a mixture of Mocking, BDD and 'integration'
tests but the comparisons will hopefully be of interest.

Cheers, Paul.
